msDesc.head: Haldenby scientific and medical commonplace book

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
Numbering in ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

p.note: NB: The collation in this record deviates from the collation of M.R. James and that provided (in pencil) by a modern hand on the outer lower corners of the first rectos of quires throughout the manuscript. While this record considers ff. 1:1r-1:4v Quire 1, these leaves were referred to as 'a' in previous collations. It also deviates from the collation of M.R. James in that it does not consider ff. 2:1r-2:32v to be an indepenent codicological unit.

note.p: Printed copy of 'Miscellanae Genealogica et Heraldica: Notes from the Fly-Leaves and Calendar of a MS. in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge (O.1.57)' on the inside of the inner cover and f. [i] recto.
An unfinished table of contents in a (?) 17th-century script on f. 2:1r: De flebotomia and De Coloribus.

A table of contents entitled Memoracio de contentis in isto libro copied in the 15th-century hand on f. 4v, followed by 5 additional entries in a later (? 16th-century) hand (the latter hand has also added folio references to the original table of contents). The original table of contents was produced when the manuscript still had 12 quires, revealing that the manuscript has since lost mathematical treatises entitled Tractatus algorismi and Tractatus de cautelis algorismi and a so-called Sphere of Life and Death called Spera pictagore.

provenance.p:
The Haldenby familyHaldenby family of Isham, Northamptonshire: compiled and owned the manuscript:
Ownership inscription on f. 2:118v: Iste liber constat Haldynby.
References to Haldenby in colophons on f. 2:16v: Wodeman ad Haldenby; f. 2:95r: quod Haldenby; and f. 2:101r: Explicit tractatus quod Haldenby [erased].
The Calendar contains the obits of John Haldenby and William Haldenby (brothers) (f. 2:2r), Robert Haldenby and Domina Matild' (f. 2:3v), probably Maud de la Carville of Isham. The Calendar also records the births of William Haldenby in 1420 (f. 2:1v) and Robert Haldenby in 1433 (f. 2:4r).
Obits for members of the Mortemer family are found on f. 1:4r and genealogical notes on f. 2:129r. William Haldenby, son of Robert Haldenby and Maud de la Carville of Isham, and John, his nephew, married, respectively, Eleanor and Joan Mortemer, daughters of John Mortermer of Grendon.

One of the manuscripts of George Carew (1555-1629) Carew, George, 1555-1629, Baron Carew of Clopton and Earl of Totnes: his signature (G: Carew) inscribed in dark ink at the top of f. 1:3v. Carew is principally known for the collection of books on Irish history that he amassed as an administrator in Ireland between 1574 and 1592. He bequeathed this collection to Sir Thomas Stafford (d. 1655), from whom they passed to William Laud (1573â1645), Archbishop of Canterbury. The latter placed forty-two volumes at Lambeth Library while four reached the Bodleian Library as part of the Laudian collection (see M.R. James, 'The Carew Manuscripts', The English Historical Review, 42 (1927), 261-267; James H. Todd, 'Account of an Ancient Irish Manuscript, in the Bodleian Library, Oxford', Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy, 2 (1936-1869), 336-346; and Ute Lotz-Heumann, 'Carew, George, earl of Totnes (1555â1629)', Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (2004) [accessed 23 February 2024]). About Carew's possession of medieval manuscripts from England much less is known, but these appear to have travelled different routes after they left his collection. His signature (G: Carew) can be found in at least six such medieval manuscripts (besides the present volume):
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.22 (f. 1v) (James, III, p. 115)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.7.23 (f. 1:1r) (James, III, pp. 361-62)
Edinburgh, University Library, MS 107 (f. 1r) [identified in the online record: 'MS 107: Composite manuscript including twenty-four texts, 13th-14th century']
London, British Library, Harley MS 204 (f. 1r)
London, British library, Harley MS 223 (f. 7r)
London, British Library, Harley MS 234 (f. 1r) (see Andrew G. Watson, The Library of Sir Simonds D'Ewes (London: British Museum, 1966), pp. 210-211 (no. 926); Cyril Ernest Wright, Fontes Harleiani: A Study of the Sources of the Harleian Collection of Manuscripts Preserved in the Department of Manuscripts in the British Museum (London: British Museum, 1972), p. 96)
It is possible that Carew received all these manuscripts from John Dee. Five of the seven aforementioned manuscripts have ownership marks associated with John Dee: while Harley MSS 204, 223, 234, and Trinity College MS O.2.21 all contain his Jupiter-marks, Trinity College MS O.7.23 â which may have featured the Jupiter-mark in the torn off upper margin of f. 1r â has been identified with an item ('M35') in the 1583 catalogue of Dee's library (see Roberts and Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (1990), p. 115).

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1672-1744, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum AngliÃ¦ et HiberniÃ¦ (1697).
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Thomas GaleGale, Thomas, son of Roger Gale (1672-1744), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark O.1.57 are printed separately on three labels pasted on the spine; its previous and current classmarks written on f. 2:1r: C.1. [crossed out], No 132, and O.1.57; its printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms and name (Collegium SS. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academica Cantabrigiensi) pasted on f. 1:3v; its book stamp on ff. 1:2r, 2:1r, 2:31v, 2:69r, 2:129r, and 2:130r.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, Vol. 3 (1902), pp. 54-58 (no. 1081); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995), pp. 175-76.; and Laura Mitchell, 'The Cultural Uses of Magic in Fifteenth-century England' (unpublished disseration, University of Toronto, 2011), pp. 257-267.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

analytic.title: Cambridge, Trinity College Library MS O.1.57 (1081)

monogr.title: Late Medieval English Magic: English manuscripts containing 15th-century magical texts

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.57, ff. 1:1-1:4

msItem.title: Easter tables for the years 1567-1617
msItem.note: Added in a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Poem on how to find Easter Day according to the new moon
msItem.incipit: 4r In marche aftur the firste C / The next prime telle thov me / Tho thryd sonedaye aftur I wys / Estur day for sothe hyt is / and if prime on the soneday falle / loke thow covnte hym firste of alle
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Genealogical entry concerning the deaths of John Mortemer and his son, John, in 1453 and 1454
msItem.incipit: 1:4r Memorandum quod Johannes Mortemer filius et heres Johannis Mortemer de Grendoun et Agnetis vxoris eue [sic: sue] obiit apud paruam Dylling .xij.mo die Augusti decima hora post horam nonam in nocte. Anno domini Millesimo .CCCC.mo quinquagesimo tercio littera dominicalis tunc .g. Et Johannes Mortemer filius et heres eius procreatur de Anna filia Georgij longvyle obijt quartodecimo die Augusti proximi sequenti Anno supra dicto
msItem.note: Full transcription.

p.seg: No ruling. Single columns. 16-23 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Folio 1:4r was copied in a cursive script with anglicana features.
Folio 1:4v was copied in a cursive script with secretary and anglicanafeatures.
Two 16th-century cursive hands have added an Easter table to f. 1:3v and entries to the table of contents on f. 4v in scripts with humanistic features.

decoNote.p: Folios 1:2v-1:3r have full-page drawings in dark ink, featuring (from left to right) a deer lying on a forest floor, an unidentified creature (? ape) in a tree, a bird of prey (? eagle) holding an empty banderole in their beak, an owl, a hare, a standing deer, a rabbit emerging from their hole, a dog biting the deer's front leg, a squirrel in a tree, and a second bird of prey (hawk) holding a lure in its claws. The two deer may be references to the White Hart-emblem used by King Richard II. This is suggested by the fact that the standing deer is displayed with heraldic imagery: it wears a royal crown with a chain around its neck (gorged and chained).

origin.origDate: First half of the 15th century, before 1454.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.57, ff. 2:1-2:32, 2:69-2:131

msItem.title: Astronomical Calendar
msItem.note: Notes regarding the Haldenby family entered into and below the Calendar: obits of John Haldenby (March 15th), Robert Haldenby (June 4th), and Matilda (June 10th); and births of William Haldenby (March 30th, 1420), and Robert Haldenby (July 15th, 1433), sons of William Haldenby of Isham.

msItem.title: Charm against fire invoking St Agatha's epitaph
msItem.rubric: 2:1v Pro igne sessandi scribatur ad euangelium in festo sancte Agathe et iactatur super ignem
msItem.incipit: 2:1v Mentem sanctam spontaneum honorem deo et patrie liberacionem
msItem.note: Full transcription; epitaph as foud in Jacobus de Voragine's Legenda Aurea.

msItem.title: Tables of eclipses of the sun, 1406-1462
msItem.rubric: 2:7r Tabula eclipsium solis pro primo ciclo
msItem.note: Accompanied by 27 circular drawings of the eclipses of the sun in blue and gold.

msItem.title: Astronomical instruction
msItem.incipit: 2:7r Ad congnoscendum quantum luminem sol vel luna pretendet oportet vos diuidere primo rotunditatem luna quasi in duodecem partes que partes vocantur pu[n]cta et tunc oportet vos numerare ea quousque perficiantur et tunc obscuro tot erunt obscuro [?] quot erunt numerato
msItem.note: Full transcription of an added instruction; accompanied by a drawing of a circle with six horizontal lines through its upper half and with the inscription sex in its lower half in dark ink.

msItem.title: Tables of eclipses of the moon, 1410-1462
msItem.rubric: 2:7v Tabula eclipsium lune pro primo ciclo
2:7v Pro 2o ciclo
2:7v Pro 3o ciclo
msItem.note: Accompanied by 22 circular drawings of the eclpises of the moon in pink and gold.

msItem.title: Table of dominical letters, 1406-1910 [!]
msItem.rubric: 2:8v Littere bisextiles / littere dominicale
msItem.note: The year 1446 is highlighted in the left margin by a different hand: Anno domini Millesimo CCCCmo .lvj..

msItem.title: Table of phases of the moon
msItem.rubric: 2:9v Tabula ad sciendum etatem lune et eius signum omni die

msItem.title: Table of the planets, the hours of the day, and humours
msItem.rubric: 2:9v Tabula docens quis planeta regnat pro qualibet hora incipiendo diem ab ortu solis

msItem.title: Zodiac Man
msItem.incipit: 2:10v Aries // Caue ab inscisione in capite vel in facie et ne scindas venam capitalem
msItem.explicit: 2:10v Pisces // Caue ne inscindaris in pedibus superius uel inferius in plantis et ne scindas venam in ilis
msItem.finalRubric: 2:10v Hic est tractatus ad docendum quando homo non debt fleubetemari - Hic sunt signa planterum
msItem.note: The text has been written around a miniature showing a naked (bearded) man with the Signs of the Zodiac at those body parts that are believed to be governed by them.

msItem.title: Tables on the length of shadows for the months and days of the year
msItem.rubric: 2:11r-2:15r Longitudines vmbrarum cuiuslibet hominis stature .6. pedum in horis de clok

msItem.title: Treatise on bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 2:15v Minucio aliqua fit per methathesim
msItem.explicit: 2:16r Et nota quod quando luna est in aliquo signorum ne minuatur in venis quae sunt implicaturae signis nec eciam supra ventose poni debent

msItem.title: Vein Man
msItem.incipit: 2:16v Uena cephalica id est capitis pro passione capitis et cerebri inscinditur
msItem.explicit: 2:16v Uena sub genu inscisa ad intra sanguinem purgat ne de percussione coaguletur
msItem.note: The text has been written around a miniature showing a naked man with red lines connecting parts of his body to the surrounding text.

msItem.title: Treatise on colours
msItem.rubric: 2:17r Sequitur de coloribus
msItem.incipit: 2:17r Vernisia fit mediante olio
msItem.explicit: 2:19r et tunc utere e statim dum humidus sunt etcaetera

msItem.title: Problemata Aristotelis
msItem.rubric: 2:19v Aristotelem
msItem.incipit: 2:10v Ego pono istum casum quod hic sunt tria animalia scilicet asinus et capra
msItem.explicit: 2:19v [not transcribed]

msItem.title: Verses on the Seven Liberal Arts
msItem.incipit: 2:20r Hic sunt septem sciencie in istis duobus versibus contente / Grammatica logica [lo]quitur / dialectica vero docet retorica vero colorat / Musica canit / ars metrica munerat / Geometrica ponderat / Astronomica docet astra
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for "scabbe" or rash on the hands
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that copied the next recipe.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for black jaundice or liver disease
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that copied the previous recipe.

msItem.title: Hempseed divination for New Year's Day
msItem.rubric: 2:20r To know who shalbe his wiffe or her husband
msItem.incipit: 2:20r Say thus: hempe seed, hempe I thee sow . lede and vnlede . she that shalbe my worldes make, come after me and rake sleepe sleepe and I her see, wake and her know. this most be done on new yeares at even taking a litle hempe seede in one hande and going thrise aboute the fier, sowing the hempe seede aboute the fier but not in the fyer . then go to bedde and lie downe vpon the right side speaking neuer a worde to no body but to say your pater noster and your Credo.
msItem.note: Full transcription.

Added by the same 16th-century hand that added medical recipes to f. 2:20v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; and all additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for "the stone' and to draw out a thorn (or another thing)
msItem.note: Added by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination to f. 2:20r; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; and all additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: Compotus manualis
msItem.incipit: 2:21r Filius esto dei celum bonus accipe grates
msItem.explicit: 2:31v sum primi alphabeti sum secundi

msItem.title: De corio serpentis
msItem.author: Johannes Paulinus
msItem.incipit: 2:69r Ego Johannes Paulus cum essem in ciuitate Alexandrina egipciorum rapui quedam librum qui sacilius appellabatur in quo ista experimenta de serpentino corio discribebantur qui quibus ista pleriumque unctam idem invenire igitur fecit Alanus propretutus experimenta tanquam ab eo tractata asserit esse verum Ego Johannes transtuli de greco in latinum
msItem.explicit: 2:70r 12m est si quis leprosus vtatur de illo puluere in questionibus eius lepra eius non poterit aumentari [sic: augmentari]

msItem.title: De signis tonitruum
msItem.author: Alfraganus
msItem.rubric: 2:70r Alfraganus de signis tonitruum
msItem.incipit: 2:70r Notandum quod in quocumque tonitruerito quicumquid signauerit
msItem.explicit: 2:70v Si in piscibus id est ffebruarius gelu et siccitas in terra fructus deficient vinum habum dabit diuicie in populo homines infirmabuntur non tum morientur

msItem.title: Treatise on the virtues of Betony
msItem.rubric: 2:70v Betonica sic legitur
msItem.incipit: 2:70v Betonica animas custodit et corpora qui secum portauerit ei nocere non poterit et habet colligi in mense Augusti ante ortum solis
msItem.explicit: 2:71v Item qui ieiuno stomaco inde biberit illo die non inebriabitur

msItem.title: List of plants and animals and their medicinal and magical properties
msItem.incipit: 2:72r Est quedam herba que aput caldios vocatur yreos aput grecos manichiel aput latinos elitropia et dicitur ab elios quod est sol et tropos conuersio quia conuersa ad solem
msItem.explicit: 2:76v leo est animal de cuius pelle si fiant corigie non timebit hostes et si de carnibus eius quis ederit et de eius aqua potauerit per tres dies a febribus quartanis pacietur et si oculi eius sub acella portantur cum inclinato capite versus yma terga dabunt
msItem.finalRubric: 2:76v Memorandum quod sunt multe hic que sunt vere et multe que sunt false

msItem.title: Three charms
msItem.textLang: Latin texts with Middle English headings
msItem.note: A charm for curing fever (invoking the name names of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit); The Three Good Brothers (Tres Boni Fratres) charm for bloodstaunching; and a charm for sleep (invoking the Seven Sleepers).

msItem.title: Two recipes for making azurite (pigment)
msItem.textLang: Latin text with a Middle English heading
msItem.rubric: 2:77v To make asure
msItem.incipit: 2:77v Si vis facere asorium optimum pone in ampuluam novam laminas purissimi argenti quantas vis
msItem.explicit: 2:77v ita dimitte vsque ad vnum mensem postea aperies ampuluam et quod inueneris in ea mitte ad solem siccare et colige

msItem.title: Collection of 20 medical recipes
msItem.rubric: 2:77v Here folowing bygynne medicinus ful gode

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Recipes added to the empty upper and lower margins by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination and medical recipes to ff. 2:20r-2:20v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; and all the additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: De ingeniis spiritualibus
msItem.author: Philo Byzantinus [Mechanicus]
msItem.incipit: 2:81r Philosophi naturales dixerunt vas vacuum non esse sed aere
msItem.explicit: 2:84v et descendet oleum paulatim a vase a. b. c. per d. e
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by 13 diagrams. Folios 82r-84v roughly correspond with the edition by Valentin Rose, Anecdota Graeca et Graeco-Latina 2 (1870) 307-313; however, this copy's opening is different and can be compared to London, British Library, Egerton MS 2662. The text is continuous with the following item.

msItem.title: Tract on geometry
msItem.incipit: 2:84v Homo iacens vultu erecto tenens
msItem.explicit: 2:85r et .a. tantus est puteus vel tanto est putei profun[?dimetro]
msItem.note: The tract is accompanied by 1 diagram. The text is continuous with the preceding and following item; unlike the preceding and following item, this tract is not present in London, British Library, Egerton MS 2662.

msItem.title: Treatise on Mensuration
msItem.incipit: 2:85r Iste tractatus vocatur tractatus arsmetrice et dicitur ars metrica de ars tis et metros mensura quasi ars mensurandi Divitur igitur iste tractatus in tres partes scilicet altimetrum planimetrum profundimetrum
msItem.explicit: 2:90v putei qui est b. f. vt patet hic
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by 22 diagrams. The text is continuous with the previous item. This text also occurs in London, British Library, Egerton MS 2662, where it immediately follows De ingeniis spiritualibus.

msItem.title: Tractatus de luna per 12 signa
msItem.incipit: 2:90v Cum lune cursum recte scire volueris
msItem.explicit: 2:95r Dum luna fuerit in piscibus possessionibus acutis congrua podagre omnibus tandem pedum viciis quantum ad medicinam spectare videtur negat [?] remedium
msItem.note: This text also occurs in Edinburgh, University Library, MS 132, f. 47v.

msItem.title: Natura Occulte
msItem.rubric: 2:95r Iam sequitur tractatus de philosophia secundum aristotelem cum causis et experimentis probantibus propositum. quod Haldenby. Amen
msItem.incipit: 2:95v Natura occulte operatur in hiis etcaetera Hoc verbum intitulatur ab auctore Sex principiorum in quo quantum ad presentem tractatum duo nominantur profunditatis scrutini et difficultatis iudicii que sunt in arte phisonominandi
msItem.explicit: 2:106r Albertus dicit quod hoc negotium fuit ab Aristotele additum, ut distingueremus inter bonos et malos per signa exteriora et ut vitia fugeremus
msItem.finalRubric: 2:106r Explicit liber Aristotelis de philosophia cum causis et experimentis probantibus propositum

msItem.title: Phisionomia Aristotelis [attributed title]
msItem.incipit: 2:106r Hanc igitur in nomine Christi et in opere nostro primo disponemus
msItem.explicit: 2:110v Et per hec omnia supradicta potest homo habere certissimam (?) cognicionem hominis

msItem.title: Treatise on chiromancy
msItem.incipit: 2:110v Cum omni humane creature sane disponente
msItem.explicit: 2:118v et studiose et cum mora et consideracione certa propiciantur ut forma iudicia non propiciantur ut iudicia non wlgentur [sic]
msItem.finalRubric: 2:118v Explicit libellus computus a magistro Johanni
msItem.note: The text is followed by a chiromantic drawing, showing a hand to which have been added the words Radix mons followed by various astrological symbols.

msItem.title: Somniale Danielis
msItem.rubric: 2:119r Hic incipit sompnia Danielis que fecit in diebus regis nabiclorum [sic] quando rogatus a principibus erat quod eis sompnia narraret et exponeret qui dicebat omnia facta a deo et non per seipsum sed a deo ista accepit et quicunque subscripta leget danielem auctorem inueniet
msItem.incipit: 2:119r Aves in sompnis viderit et cum eis pugnare lucrum significat aues vel apes in sompnis videre capere lucrum
msItem.explicit: 2:124r Zonam vertem singi languorem significat etcaetera

msItem.title: Six recipes for trick inks
msItem.incipit: 2:124r Item super cum aqua scribere volueris in calibe
msItem.explicit: 2:125r et ibi in pone in caustum prius dictum et ibi corrodes litteras bonas

msItem.title: Scribal poem
msItem.incipit: 2:125r Si mea penna valet melior mea litera fiet / Nomen scriptoris Willelmus plenis amoris / Omnibus omnia non mea sompnia dicere possum / Dum calor est et pulcra dies formica laborat

msItem.title: Tracts on the signs of pregnancy in a woman (with signs to establish the sex of a child and to identify a dead child)
msItem.incipit: 2:125r yf a woman be with childe, her water is white . Yf she have gone a moneth or ij or .3. her water shalbe verey white and clere
msItem.explicit: 2:125r Item fourthlie her eyen be small or small than they be wont to be
msItem.note: Added by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination and medical recipes to ff. 2:20r-2:20v; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; and all the additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: Four hare-based recipes for enhancing conception
msItem.rubric: 2:125v Ad conceptionem
msItem.incipit: 2:125v Accipe matricem leporis desiccatam et puluerizetur et muliere exeunti a balneo offeratur cum vino tepido et muscato et infra horam sequentem facta desiccate [?] corporis accedat ad coitum
msItem.explicit: 2:125v Item leporis vulua assatu et in puluerem redacta et cum vino mulieri data in balneo ipsa die si coierit concipiet
msItem.note: Added by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination and medical recipes to ff. 2:20r-2:20v; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; and other additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: Two substances that can make both women urinate and sex workers not conceive
msItem.incipit: 2:125v Lappacium combustum coram femina velit nolit minget. Meretrices suffumigant se lolio ne concipiant
msItem.explicit: 2:125v Item propter eadem causam portant super se argentum vinum
msItem.note: Full transcription.

Added by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination and medical recipes to ff. 2:20r-2:20v; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; and other additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: A method for establishing a woman's virginity
msItem.incipit: 2:125v Take a woman to drinke the iuyce of redde nettell and if she make no water anon virge est
msItem.note: Full transcription.

Added by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination and medical recipes to ff. 1:20r-1:20v; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; and other additions to f. 2:125v.

msItem.title: Medical recipe against a sexually transmitted disease ('pruritus virgae')
msItem.note: Added by the same 16th-century hand that added an instruction for hempseed divination and medical recipes to ff. 2:20r-2:20v; medical recipes to the upper and lower margins of ff. 2:76v-2:80v; a tract on the signs of pregnancy in a woman on f. 2:125r; and other additions to f. 1:125v.

msItem.title: A charm to retrieve stolen things
msItem.textLang: Latin text with Middle English words
msItem.incipit: 2:126v Item pro rebus ablatis Recipe vnum panem et fac in parte inferiori ho [sic] signum [pentangle in black and red ink with cross in center and letters a through e in outside angles between points]] quo facto recipe iij cultellos et infiges per latera panis
msItem.explicit: 2:126v I prey to god almyty fadur alweldyng sone and stedfast holy gost os Ã¾o brake .v. lowes [corrected with a "u" written above the "w"] And .v. fyshys on schere thursday in myraclys to [t]y desiplys gaf gyf grace Ã¾ys lof to turne a boute with Ã¾o gylty Et cum inposuerit nomen rei vertet se panis

msItem.title: IHS Monogram
msItem.note: The capital letters IHS outlies in red ink and partially filled in with dark ink.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for worms in teeth
msItem.rubric: 2:127r Pro uermibus in dentibus alicuius

msItem.title: Method to protect oneself against enemies while eating using chamomile
msItem.rubric: 2:127r Camamilla est herba que si teneatur manu sedentes in prandio inimicus tuus non habebit potestatem comedendi tecum

msItem.title: Game involving 24 stones to be divided between three players
msItem.rubric: 2:127r Ad sciendum de tribus hominibus et de tribus res quis illorum accipiperit optimam rem quis secundam et quis tertiam
msItem.incipit: 2:127r Accipe .xx.ti iiijor lapides et da .vni. vnum . alteri:
msItem.explicit: 2:127v et si tres tunc j habent etcaetera vt patet per versum: Salue stella . maris . autrix . rictrex. veni rite

msItem.title: Magical trick for making a house appear to be filled with water
msItem.rubric: 2:127v Ad faciendum domum apparere plenum aque accipe ouum alice adyl pone in quadriuio per spacium trium dierum et trium noctum sub terra et tunc accipe ouum et frange in vase et tunc accipe filum duplicatum et madefac illum in ouo pone circa postem domus et sic apparebit
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Magical trick to make fire dance around a house
msItem.incipit: 2:127v Ad faciendum ignem currere circa domum accipe encensum et mole bene et pone in manu tua cum candela illuminata et iacta circa domum et sic apparebit
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Latin verbs with English glosses
msItem.author: John Leylond [attributed]
msItem.incipit: 2:127vFimare stercorare arare seminare erpicare runcare metere congelimare vectitare artonisare flagellare uel tritutare id est venticare molere cribrare pollentrudiare malaxere fermentare costare almun formare panem infurnare pinsere effuruare non possumus vno die
msItem.finalRubric: 2:127vHic sunt plura latina verba in ista latinitate contenta secundum Johannem leylond
msItem.note: Full transcription; a hand has added English translations for the verbs in glosses above the words: to moke for stercorare; to ere for arare; to sowe for seminare; to harow for erpicare; to wede for runcare; to schere for metere; to schocke for congelimare; to carry for vectimare; to mowe for artonisare; to Ã¾resche for flagellare; to wyndow for venticare; to grynde for molere; to syfte for cribrare; to bulte for pollentrudiare; to knede for malaxare; to sowre for fermentare; to shap for costare; Ã¾o howe for almun; to molde for formare; Ã¾o bred for panem; to sethin for infurnare; to paycke for pinsere; to drawe owte for effuruare.

For another copy, see Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 417/447 (Nicholas Orme, 'An English Grammar SChool ca. 1450: Latin Exercises from Exeter (Caius College MS 417/447, Folios 16v-24v)', Traditio, 50 (1995), 261-294 (p. 286)).

msItem.title: The Tricks of Solomon
msItem.incipit: 2:128r Hic dicendum est de ludis salomonis de igne tonitruo volante super cordam de igne volante in animere ad modum draconis de aqua ardente et de speculo ardente
msItem.explicit: 2:128v Si vis facere pannum et faciem alicuius ardere sine lesione accipe classam et fac inde puluerem et pone super palmam manus tue et post illuminam candelam et retine inter digitos tuos et proice puluerem in candela et sit apparebit
msItem.note: The tract only lists the purposes of certain tricks, e.g. making fire fly through the air like a dragon, making clothing burn without damaging it, making robbers appear to be hanged in a house, learning a woman's secrets and whether she is a virgin or not. Embedded in this list are also three recipes for making gunpowder, alcohol, and a burning mirror (f. 2:128v) that relate to the listed tricks.

msItem.title: Genealogical notes
msItem.incipit: 2:129r Laurencius Henkoc alias dictus Laurencius Clerke habuit exitus Thomas
msItem.explicit: 2:129r dicta Petronella maritata fuit Edmundo Mortemer et habuerit exitus Laurencius Mortemer et dicus Laurencius habuit in vxorem sorore \Johannis et Patris/ Henrici Sewell et habuerit exitus Johannem Mortem[er] de Grendoun
msItem.note: See Joseph Howard, Miscellanea Genealogica Et Heraldica: Vol. I (1874), pp. 246-247.

msItem.title: Astrological note
msItem.incipit: 2:130r Tibertus [Venum] ponit vbi [Mercurius] est et [Mercurium] vbi [Mars] est et [Martem] in loco [Veneris]

msItem.title: Full-page illustratrions of chiromantic hands (left hand and right hand)
msItem.note: The drawing of the right hand is accompanied by a legend that connnects initials drawn on the hand to planets and other astronomical phenomena, including the Milky Way ("via lactea") and the Belt of Venus ("Cingulum veneris"), as described in the works of Robert Fludd (1574-1647). This astrological list is followed by a second list that gives the Latin names of bones and muscles in the hand.

msItem.title: Scribal saying
msItem.incipit: 2:130v Si mea penna vale[t] melior mea littera ffiet
msItem.note: Full transcription.
Added in the 15th or 16th century.

msItem.title: Two lists of English words
msItem.incipit: 2:130v yelow - content
msItem.explicit: 2:130v violet - love
msItem.note: The first list contains colours, the second one emotions.
Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Practice words
msItem.incipit: 2:130v oreng tawnie . I wold I myght
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Poem about consanguineous relations and childeren
msItem.incipit: 2:131r Patre suo natum si filia concipit unum / Rursus et in matrem generat puerum puer iste / Tunc pater extremo poterit sic dicere nato / Tu meus est frater filius atque nepos
msItem.note: Full transcription.

catchwords.seg: Occasional catchwords in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 22-30 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The description of the hands is based on Mitchell (2011) [see pp. 257-260 where further details about the hands are provided].
Hand A has copied the genealogical entries on ff. 1:4r and 2:129r, and the medical recipes on f. 2:20r in an anglicana script with some secretary influences.
Hand B has copied ff. 2:1r-2:16v in in an anglicana script with some secretary influences.
Hand C has copied ff. 2:17r-2:19r in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand D has copied ff. 2:19v and 2:20r in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand E has copied ff. 2:21r in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand F has copied ff. 2:69r-2:80v in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand G has copied ff. 2:81r-2:95r in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand H has copied ff. 2:95v-2:124r in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand I has copied ff. 2:124r-2:125r and 2:127r-2:128v in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand J has copied f. 2:126v in a cursive script with both anglicana and secretary features.
Hand K has made later marginal additions throughout the manuscrip in a secretary script with anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Vein Man: a miniature showing a naked man in colours with red lines connecting parts of his body to the surrounding text on f. 2:16v.
Zodiac Man: a miniature showing a naked bearded man with the Signs of the Zodiac in colours and gold on f. 2:10v.
49 circular drawings of solar and lunar eclipses in blue and gold or pink and gold on ff. 2:7r-2:7v.

A diagrammatic astronomical drawing in brown ink, consisting of a circle (the moon) with six horizontal lines through its upper half and with the inscription sex in its lower half in dark ink on 2:7r.

26 diagrams in brown ink drawn inside spaces that have been left open for them by the scribe on ff. 2:81r-2:90v, featuring geometric figures, vessels, and architectural structures (e.g. towers and a castle gate) in brown ink.
Chiromantic diagrams of hands in brown ink on ff. 2:118v, 2:129v, 2:130.

Two diagrammatic drawings in dark and red ink within a text that describes a magic ritual for retrieving stolen goods on on f. 2:126v: 1. A pentangle with a cross drawn inside it and the letters "a" to "e" written on the outside between successive points in dark ink illustrating a figure that needs to be drawn on bread 2. A diagram showing the bread after it has been pierced by three knives.

Large blue initials (2- or 3-line, and one 4-line on f. 2:21r) with penwork decoration in red ink inside the letters (foliate motifs), in frames of red penwork, and with pen-flourishing in red ink extending into the margins throughout.
A IHS monogram in large letters (Gothic Textualis) outlined in dark and red ink on f. 2:126v.
Large 'KL' plain capitals in blue ink written above the Calendar tables on ff. 2:1r-2:6v.
Small (1-line) plain initials in blue or red in the Calendar tables on ff. 2:1r-2:6v, and the astrological texts on ff. 2:10v and 2:16v.
Line-fillers consisting of rows of red 'tildes' throughout.
Occasional cadels highlighted in red ink on extenders of letters on the first lines of pages (e.g. see ff. 2:72r-2:77r).
Rubricated numbers in tables, sub-headers in texts, and explicits.
Regular initials higlighted with red ink throughout.
Paraphs in blue or red ink throughout.
Sub-headers in texts occasionally written in frames of red ink.

origin.origDate: First half of the 15th century, before 1454.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
